meanings.definition: To put to death by nailing or binding the hands and feet to a cross.
meanings.sent1: The Romans would crucify criminals as a form of punishment.
meanings.sent2: The soldiers decided to crucify the prisoner for his crimes.
meanings.sent3: I hope they don't crucify me for forgetting my friend's birthday.
meanings.sent4: The media can sometimes crucify celebrities for minor mistakes.
meanings.sent5: The image of Jesus on the cross crucifies the hearts of believers with sorrow.

meanings.definition: To treat with gross injustice or cruelty.
meanings.sent1: It's unfair to crucify someone for a simple mistake.
meanings.sent2: The dictator would crucify anyone who opposed his rule.
meanings.sent3: Please don't crucify me for accidentally spilling the milk.
meanings.sent4: The harsh words of the bully seemed to crucify the young student's spirit.
meanings.sent5: The cruel actions of the villain crucify the hopes of the innocent townspeople.

meanings.sent1: Some people tend to crucify others for their different opinions.
meanings.sent2: The movie critics would crucify any film that didn't meet their standards.
meanings.sent3: I don't want to crucify your efforts, but there is room for improvement.
meanings.sent4: Her self-doubt would often crucify her confidence before important presentations.
meanings.sent5: The teacher's words seemed to crucify the student's enthusiasm for learning.
